parties.name: Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program: Program Management Office
Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program: Joint Authorization Board

constraints.description: monthly for privileged accessed, every six (6) months for non-privileged access
no more than 24 hours from last use
thirty-five (35) days (See additional requirements and guidance.)
inactivity is anticipated to exceed Fifteen (15) minutes
organization-defined need with justification statement that explains why such accounts are necessary
at a minimum, the ISSO and/or similar role within the organization
all security-relevant information not publicly available
any software except software explicitly documented
locks the account/node for a minimum of three (3) hours or until unlocked by an administrator
three (3) sessions for privileged access and two (2) sessions for non-privileged access
fifteen (15) minutes; requiring the user to initiate a device lock before leaving the system unattended
five (5) years or 5 years after completion of a specific training program

successful and unsuccessful account logon events, account management events, object access, policy change, privilege functions, process tracking, and system events. For Web applications: all administrator activity, authentication checks, authorization checks, data deletions, data access, data changes, and permission changes
organization-defined subset of the auditable events defined in AU-2a to be audited continually for each identified event.
annually or whenever there is a change in the threat environment

session, connection, transaction, or activity duration; for client-server transactions, the number of bytes received and bytes sent; additional informational messages to diagnose or identify the event; characteristics that describe or identify the object or resource being acted upon; individual identities of group account users; full-text of privileged commands
service provider personnel with authority to address failed audit events
audit failure events requiring real-time alerts, as defined by organization audit policy
Selection (one or more): vulnerability scanning information; performance data; information system monitoring information; penetration test data;
one second granularity of time measurement
minimum actions including the addition, modification, deletion, approval, sending, or receiving of data
all information system and network components where audit capability is deployed/available
all network, data storage, and computing devices
service provider-defined individuals or roles with audit configuration responsibilities
all network, data storage, and computing devices
individuals or roles to include FedRAMP PMO
at least annually and on input from JAB/AO
at least every three (3) years or when a significant change occurs
at least annually or when a significant change occurs
to include when directed by the JAB
organization-defined number of previous versions of baseline configurations of the previously approved baseline configuration of IS components
organization defined configuration management approval authorities
Configuration control board (CCB) or similar (as defined in CM-3)
All security safeguards that rely on cryptography
at least quarterly or when there is a change
Continuously, using automated mechanisms with a maximum five-minute delay in detection.
time period defined in service provider and organization SLA
time period and transfer rate consistent with the recovery time and recovery point objectives defined in the service provider and organization SLA.
time period consistent with the restoration time-periods defined in the service provider and organization SLA
FIPS 140, NIAP Certification, or NSA approval
at a minimum, the ISSO (or similar role within the organization)
organization-defined composition, including at least 50% of the password changed when new passwords are created; and prohibits password reuse for twenty four (24) generations
at least every six (6) months, including functional at least annually
all network, data storage, and computing devices
US-CERT incident reporting timelines as specified in NIST Special Publication 800-61 (as amended)
see additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance
see additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance
any digital and non-digital media deemed sensitive
all types of digital and non-digital media with sensitive information
see additional FedRAMP requirements and guidance
prior to leaving secure/controlled environment: for digital media, encryption using a FIPS 140 validated encryption module; for non-digital media, secured in locked container
techniques and procedures IAW NIST SP 800-88 Section 4: Reuse and Disposal of Storage Media and Hardware
CSP defined physical access control systems/devices AND guards
in all circumstances within restricted access area where the information system resides
for a minimum of one (1) year
service provider building maintenance/physical security personnel
service provider emergency responders with incident response responsibilities
consistent with American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE) document entitled Thermal Guidelines for Data Processing Environments
service provider building maintenance/physical security personnel
physical and environmental hazards identified during threat assessment
at least annually and when the rules are revised or changed
at least annually or when a significant change occurs

for national security clearances; a reinvestigation is required during the fifth (5th) year for top secret security clearance, the tenth (10th) year for secret security clearance, and fifteenth (15th) year for confidential security clearance.

For moderate risk law enforcement and high impact public trust level, a reinvestigation is required during the fifth (5th) year. There is no reinvestigation for other moderate risk positions or any low risk positions
access control personnel responsible for disabling access to the system
at least annually and any time there is a change to the user's level of access
terminations: immediately; transfers: within twenty-four (24) hours
at a minimum, the ISSO and/or similar role within the organization
at least annually or whenever a significant change occurs
monthly operating system/infrastructure; monthly web applications (including APIs) and databases

high-risk vulnerabilities mitigated within thirty (30) days from date of discovery; moderate-risk vulnerabilities mitigated within ninety (90) days from date of discovery; low risk vulnerabilities mitigated within one hundred and eighty (180) days from date of discovery
notify appropriate service provider personnel and follow procedures for organization and service provider-defined corrective actions
at a minimum to include security-relevant external system interfaces; high-level design; low-level design; source code or network and data flow diagram;
at a minimum, the ISSO (or similar role within the organization)
Appropriate FedRAMP Security Controls Baseline (s) if Federal information is processed or stored within the external system
Federal/FedRAMP Continuous Monitoring requirements must be met for external systems where Federal information is processed or stored
all external systems where Federal information is processed or stored
information processing, information or data, AND system services
U.S./U.S. Territories or geographic locations where there is U.S. jurisdiction
all High impact data, systems, or services
as needed and as dictated by the current threat posture
organization and service provider- defined security requirements
at a minimum: ICMP (ping) flood, SYN flood, slowloris, buffer overflow attack, and volume attack
at least every ninety (90) days or whenever there is a change in the threat environment that warrants a review of the exceptions
Host Intrusion Prevention System (HIPS), Host Intrusion Detection System (HIDS), or minimally a host-based firewall
prevent unauthorized disclosure of information AND detect changes to information
no longer than ten (10) minutes for privileged sessions and no longer than fifteen (15) minutes for user sessions
all information system components storing customer data deemed sensitive
within thirty (30) days of release of updates
to include endpoints and network entry and exit points
to include blocking and quarantining malicious code and alerting administrator or defined security personnel near-realtime
to include system security personnel and administrators with configuration/patch-management responsibilities
to include upon system startup and/or restart
to include system administrators and security personnel
selection to include security relevant event
notification of supply chain compromises and results of assessment or audits

parts.name: item
parts.title: AC-2 (3) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider defines the time period for non-user accounts (e.g., accounts associated with devices). The time periods are approved and accepted by the JAB/AO. Where user management is a function of the service, reports of activity of consumer users shall be made available.

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider defines the time period of inactivity for device identifiers.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: For DoD clouds, see DoD cloud website for specific DoD requirements that go above and beyond FedRAMP https://public.cyber.mil/dccs/.

parts.name: item
parts.title: AC-2 (5) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Should use a shorter timeframe than AC-12.

parts.name: item
parts.title: AC-2 (9) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.title: AC-2 (12) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Required for privileged accounts.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Required for privileged accounts.

parts.name: item
parts.title: AC-5 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: CSPs have the option to provide a separation of duties matrix as an attachment to the SSP.

parts.name: item
parts.title: AC-6 (2) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Examples of security functions include but are not limited to: establishing system accounts, configuring access authorizations (i.e., permissions, privileges), setting events to be audited, and setting intrusion detection parameters, system programming, system and security administration, other privileged functions.

parts.name: item
parts.title: AC-8 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider shall determine elements of the cloud environment that require the System Use Notification control. The elements of the cloud environment that require System Use Notification are approved and accepted by the JAB/AO.

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider shall determine how System Use Notification is going to be verified and provide appropriate periodicity of the check. The System Use Notification verification and periodicity are approved and accepted by the JAB/AO.

parts.name: item
parts.prose: If not performed as part of a Configuration Baseline check, then there must be documented agreement on how to provide results of verification and the necessary periodicity of the verification by the service provider. The documented agreement on how to provide verification of the results are approved and accepted by the JAB/AO.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: If performed as part of a Configuration Baseline check, then the % of items requiring setting that are checked and that pass (or fail) check can be provided.

parts.name: item
parts.title: AU-2 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Coordination between service provider and consumer shall be documented and accepted by the JAB/AO.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Annually or whenever changes in the threat environment are communicated to the service provider by the JAB/AO.

parts.name: item
parts.title: AU-3 (1) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: For client-server transactions, the number of bytes sent and received gives bidirectional transfer information that can be helpful during an investigation or inquiry.

parts.name: item
parts.title: AU-6 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Coordination between service provider and consumer shall be documented and accepted by the JAB/AO. In multi-tennant environments, capability and means for providing review, analysis, and reporting to consumer for data pertaining to consumer shall be documented.

parts.name: item
parts.title: AU-6 (6) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Coordination between service provider and consumer shall be documented and accepted by the JAB/AO.

parts.name: item
parts.title: AU-11 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider retains audit records on-line for at least ninety days and further preserves audit records off-line for a period that is in accordance with NARA requirements.

parts.name: item
parts.title: CA-2 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: See the FedRAMP Documents page> Annual Assessment Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.title: CA-2 (1) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: For JAB Authorization, must use an accredited 3PAO.

parts.name: item
parts.title: CA-2 (2) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: To include 'announced', 'vulnerability scanning'

parts.name: item
parts.title: CA-5 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: POA&Ms must be provided at least monthly.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: See the FedRAMP Documents page> Plan of Action and Milestones (POA&M) Template Completion Guide

parts.name: item
parts.title: CA-6 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Significant change is defined in NIST Special Publication 800-37 Revision 2, Appendix F. The service provider describes the types of changes to the information system or the environment of operations that would impact the risk posture. The types of changes are approved and accepted by the JAB/AO.

parts.name: item
parts.title: CA-7 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Operating System Scans: at least monthly. Database and Web Application Scans: at least monthly. All scans performed by Independent Assessor: at least annually

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: CSPs must provide evidence of closure and remediation of high vulnerabilities within the timeframe for standard POA&M updates.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: See the FedRAMP Documents> Continuous Monitoring Strategy Guide

parts.name: item
parts.title: CM-2 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: See the FedRAMP Documents page> Penetration Test Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.title: CM-3 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Significant change is defined in NIST Special Publication 800-37 Revision 2, Appendix F.

parts.name: item
parts.title: CM-6 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider establishes a central means of communicating major changes to or developments in the information system or environment of operations that may affect its services to the federal government and associated service consumers (e.g., electronic bulletin board, web status page). The means of communication are approved and accepted by the JAB/AO.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: In accordance with record retention policies and procedures.

parts.name: item
parts.title: CM-7 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Information on the USGCB can be found at: https://csrc.nist.gov/projects/united-states-government-configuration-baseline.

parts.name: item
parts.title: CM-7 (2) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider shall use the DoD STIGs or Center for Internet Security guidelines to establish list of prohibited or restricted functions, ports, protocols, and/or services or establishes its own list of prohibited or restricted functions, ports, protocols, and/or services if USGCB is not available.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Information on the USGCB checklists can be found at: https://csrc.nist.gov/projects/united-states-government-configuration-baseline.

parts.name: item
parts.title: CM-8 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: This control shall be implemented in a technical manner on the information system to only allow programs to run that adhere to the policy (i.e. white listing). This control is not to be based off of strictly written policy on what is allowed or not allowed to run.

parts.name: item
parts.title: CP-2 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: must be provided at least monthly or when there is a change.

parts.name: item
parts.title: CP-4 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: For JAB authorizations the contingency lists include designated FedRAMP personnel.

parts.name: item
parts.title: CP-7 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider develops test plans in accordance with NIST Special Publication 800-34 (as amended); plans are approved by the JAB/AO prior to initiating testing.

parts.name: item
parts.title: CP-7 (1) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider defines a time period consistent with the recovery time objectives and business impact analysis.

parts.name: item
parts.title: CP-8 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: The service provider may determine what is considered a sufficient degree of separation between the primary and alternate processing sites, based on the types of threats that are of concern. For one particular type of threat (i.e., hostile cyber attack), the degree of separation between sites will be less relevant.

parts.name: item
parts.title: CP-9 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider defines a time period consistent with the recovery time objectives and business impact analysis.

parts.name: item
parts.title: IA-2 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider shall determine what elements of the cloud environment require the Information System Backup control. The service provider shall determine how Information System Backup is going to be verified and appropriate periodicity of the check.

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider maintains at least three backup copies of user-level information (at least one of which is available online) or provides an equivalent alternative.

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider maintains at least three backup copies of system-level information (at least one of which is available online) or provides an equivalent alternative.

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider maintains at least three backup copies of information system documentation including security information (at least one of which is available online) or provides an equivalent alternative.

parts.name: item
parts.title: IA-2 (6) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: For all control enhancements that specify multifactor authentication, the implementation must adhere to the Digital Identity Guidelines specified in NIST Special Publication 800-63B.

parts.name: item
parts.title: IA-2 (12) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: PIV=separate device. Please refer to NIST SP 800-157 Guidelines for Derived Personal Identity Verification (PIV) Credentials.

parts.name: item
parts.title: IA-5 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Include Common Access Card (CAC), i.e., the DoD technical implementation of PIV/FIPS 201/HSPD-12.

parts.name: item
parts.title: IA-5 (1) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Authenticators must be compliant with NIST SP 800-63-3 Digital Identity Guidelines IAL, AAL, FAL level 3. Link https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3

parts.name: item
parts.title: IA-12 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Guidance: If password policies are compliant with NIST SP 800-63B Memorized Secret (Section 5.1.1) Guidance, the control may be considered compliant

parts.name: item
parts.title: IA-12 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Guidance: In accordance with NIST SP 800-63A Enrollment and Identity Proofing

parts.name: item
parts.title: IR-3-2 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Guidance: In accordance with NIST SP 800-63A Enrollment and Identity Proofing

parts.name: item
parts.title: IR-4 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider defines tests and/or exercises in accordance with NIST Special Publication 800-61 (as amended). Functional testing must occur prior to testing for initial authorization. Annual functional testing may be concurrent with required penetration tests (see CA-8). The service provider provides test plans to the JAB/AO annually. Test plans are approved and accepted by the JAB/AO prior to test commencing.

parts.name: item
parts.title: IR-6 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider ensures that individuals conducting incident handling meet personnel security requirements commensurate with the criticality/sensitivity of the information being processed, stored, and transmitted by the information system.

parts.name: item
parts.title: IR-8 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Reports security incident information according to FedRAMP Incident Communications Procedure.

parts.name: item
parts.title: MP-3 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider defines a list of incident response personnel (identified by name and/or by role) and organizational elements. The incident response list includes designated FedRAMP personnel.

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider defines a list of incident response personnel (identified by name and/or by role) and organizational elements. The incident response list includes designated FedRAMP personnel.

parts.name: item
parts.title: MP-4 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Second parameter not-applicable

parts.name: item
parts.title: MP-5 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider defines controlled areas within facilities where the information and information system reside.

parts.name: item
parts.title: MP-6 (2) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider defines security measures to protect digital and non-digital media in transport. The security measures are approved and accepted by the JAB/AO.

parts.name: item
parts.title: PE-14 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Equipment and procedures may be tested or validated for effectiveness

parts.name: item
parts.title: PL-8 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider measures temperature at server inlets and humidity levels by dew point.

parts.name: item
parts.title: PL-10 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Significant change is defined in NIST Special Publication 800-37 Revision 2, Appendix F.

parts.name: item
parts.title: RA-3 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Select the appropriate FedRAMP Baseline

parts.name: item
parts.title: RA-5 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Include all Authorizing Officials; for JAB authorizations to include FedRAMP.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Significant change is defined in NIST Special Publication 800-37 Revision 2, Appendix F.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SA-4 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: an accredited independent assessor scans operating systems/infrastructure, web applications, and databases once annually.

parts.name: item
parts.prose: to include all Authorizing Officials; for JAB authorizations to include FedRAMP

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: See the FedRAMP Documents page> Vulnerability Scanning Requirements

parts.name: item
parts.title: SA-10 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The service provider must comply with Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) Subpart 7.103, and Section 889 of the John S. McCain National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) for Fiscal Year 2019 (Pub. L. 115-232), and FAR Subpart 4.21, which implements Section 889 (as well as any added updates related to FISMA to address security concerns in the system acquisitions process).

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: The use of Common Criteria (ISO/IEC 15408) evaluated products is strongly preferred.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SC-7 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: track security flaws and flaw resolution within the system, component, or service and report findings to organization-defined personnel, to include FedRAMP.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SC-7 (5) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: SC-7 (b) should be met by subnet isolation. VLAN separation will be considered when it provides the same protection as subnet separation.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SC-8 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: For JAB Authorization, CSPs shall include details of this control in their Architecture Briefing

parts.name: item
parts.title: SC-8 (1) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: For each instance of data in transit, confidentiality AND integrity should be through cryptography as specified in SC-8 (1), or physical means as specified in SC-8 (5).

parts.name: item
parts.title: SC-12 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: SC-8 (1) applies when encryption has been selected as the method to protect confidentiality and integrity. Otherwise refer to SC-8 (5). SC-8 (1) is strongly encouraged.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SC-13 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Federally approved cryptography

parts.name: item
parts.title: SC-15 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: This control applies to all use of cryptography. In addition to encryption, this includes functions such as hashing, random number generation, and key generation. Examples include the following:

parts.name: item
parts.title: SC-20 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: The information system provides disablement (instead of physical disconnect) of collaborative computing devices in a manner that supports ease of use.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SC-21 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Control Description should include how DNSSEC is implemented on authoritative DNS servers to supply valid responses to external DNSSEC requests.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SC-28 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Control description should include how DNSSEC is implemented on recursive DNS servers to make DNSSEC requests when resolving DNS requests from internal components to domains external to the CSO boundary.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SC-28 (1) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: The organization supports the capability to use cryptographic mechanisms to protect information at rest.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SI-4 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Organizations should select a mode of protection that is targeted towards the relevant threat scenarios.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SI-4 (5) Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: See US-CERT Incident Response Reporting Guidelines.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SI-8 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: In accordance with the incident response plan.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SR-3 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: When CSO sends email on behalf of the government as part of the business offering, Control Description should include implementation of Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC) on the sending domain for outgoing messages as described in DHS Binding Operational Diderective (BOD) 18-01.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SR-6 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: CSO must document and maintain the supply chain custody, including replacement devices, to ensure the integrity of the devices before being introduced to the boundary.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SR-8 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: CSOs must ensure that their supply chain vendors build and test their systems in alignment with NIST SP 800-171 or a commensurate security and compliance framework. CSOs must ensure that vendors are compliant with physical facility access and logical access controls to supplied products.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SR-9 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: CSOs must ensure and document how they receive notifications from their supply chain vendor of newly discovered vulnerabilities including zero-day vulnerabilities.

parts.name: item
parts.title: SR-11 Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

parts.name: item
parts.prose: CSOs must ensure vendors provide authenticity of software and patches supplied to the service provider including documenting the safeguards in place.
